awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Computational Sensing for Human-centered AI
awd_abstract_narration:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site in Computational Sensing for Human-centered Artificial Intelligence recognizes that the boundaries between human-computer interaction (HCI) and artificial intelligence (AI) are blurring and that AI is growing increasingly agile and pervasive. Thus, the next generation of computational scientists must be capable of responsibly and effectively leveraging a spectrum of sensing data from data-generating humans. With this focus, the REU Site will expand its trajectory as an attractor for highly diverse students, including women or gender minorities and students with disabilities, who will gain experience with sensing hardware and software towards transformative advances in intelligent systems focused on human behaviors and cognitive processes. Enabling diverse stakeholders early in their careers to discover how to collect, fuse, make inference with, and visualize multimodal human data helps nurture a workforce that can transform how humans and machines engage and collaborate. The research in the REU Site will address two limitations in AI: first, that underserved populations are at risk of being marginalized with the present focus on big data AI and, second, that AI trainees often lack experience with human data collection and critical thinking about human-elicited datasets. The REU Site will stimulate novel, safe ways for systems to team up with people to address society's vexing problems while remaining fair, attuned to bias, and representative of the diverse fabric of the general population. 

The REU Site in Computational Sensing for Human-centered Artificial Intelligence sets three ambitious and attainable goals and will publish widely on the findings at computational and Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) research and education venues: (1) to advance basic research in computational sensing for human-centered AI, integrating human study with sound AI experimentation focused on modestly-sized, inclusive datasets; (2) to develop programmatic mechanisms for aiding students to transition confidently from being taught to being mentored by research faculty and ensure their readiness for entering computer science/STEM PhD programs; and (3) to enhance and intensify our recruiting strategies with the aim of doubling Native American or Latina/o students and students with disabilities among our applicant pool, as well as reach even more demanding selection targets for exceptionally diverse cohorts. We link these objectives to four associated Site aims: (a) to offer team-based research with real-world problems that emphasize social good and impact; (b) to cost-effectively enable global awareness and skills-building, by facilitating on-campus international cultural exchange for REU cohorts; (c) to provide outreach enrichment for cohorts to learn how to communicate research broadly; and (d) to disseminate lessons learned from the REU Site to the scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

As part of the REU Site in Computational Sensing for Human-centered AI, 33 undergraduate students experienced team-based research with multimodal human sensing data, including how to collect, fuse, model with, and visualize multimodal human data. In 2019, we held an in-person REU Site. In 2020, the program had a hiatus year. In 2021, the second REU Site cohort participated in a migrated online program format, and we included an additional student supported part-time by a supplement, in addition to the regular cohort of 10 students. In 2022, we returned to an in-person format for the third cohort. Finally, the organizers mentored two additional undergraduate students in research until the end of the award.

The research from this REU Site project resulted in 14 research publications, most of which were first-authored by REU students. The published manuscripts that resulted from specific team-based research projects included approximately 20 REU students in addition to faculty mentors. Some publications were co-authored by graduate students. We also increased the dissemination of knowledge generated about the REU Site undergraduate research training framework to the computing and STEM education research community, publishing on strategies to offer online, remote research experiences, and our strategies for supporting students to transition from being taught in courses to engaging in mentored research. In addition, REU students presented research projects at RIT's annual undergraduate research symposium. Some of these presentations used a virtual video format. Four REU students also delivered presentations at the REU CUR symposium. Additionally, this project resulted in other products such as a web-based multimodal data visualization software prototype for data analysis, collected multimodal data, source code, algorithms, as well as materials for training, assessment, and communication associated with the REU Site. The cohorts benefited from a comprehensive program of professional development activities such as workshops, a journal club, sessions with faculty mentors sharing their research expertise, and a mentoring event with doctoral students.

The REU Site PI and Co-PI also contributed to the organizing committee of the Workshop on Human-centered Computational Sensing in 2020, 2022, and 2024 co-located with IEEE PerCom. With other local REU Sites, we co-organized an REU Graduate Study and Research Symposium, held in-person in 2019 and 2022 versus online in 2021. In terms of long-term research community building, in 2021, we additionally held an online five-year alumni celebration, connecting REU student alumni, going back to our initial REU Site, with the cohort of students who then participated in the program. 

 Broader Impacts:

Average cohort demographics (30 students) included 97% from outside RIT, 80% computing majors, 57% from institutions with limited access to research opportunities in computing, 63% women or other gender minorities, 33% from years earlier than college junior (at time of application), 40% AALANA, and 23% reporting a disability. The additional three participants included 1 female and 2 male RIT undergraduate students in computing disciplines. Some participants had the opportunity to engage in STEM outreach at a public library.

A student was later offered a GRFP fellowship and another a Goldwater fellowship. In addition, two were recognized with Last Mile fellowships, and one as a Hispanic Scholarship Fund scholar. We also offered the students international skills-building opportunities. One cohort interacted with two students visiting RIT's campus from overseas, and cohorts interacted online with achievement talk evaluators based in Europe. Three PhD students from computing and information sciences or engineering benefited from their involvement in research co-mentoring of REU student research projects, research publication co-authorship, and learning about REU Site operations as assistants. In addition, the PI and Co-PI served the NSF CISE REU Site community by contributing to the organizing committees of either the PI and New PI meetings in multiple years.
